title: 109_hr4318
content: The "Outer Continental Shelf Natural Gas Relief Act" terminates prohibitions on expenditures for offshore gas leasing and revokes withdrawals of Federal submerged lands for leasing. It also introduces state approval requirements for gas leasing. The Secretary cannot grant gas leases within 20 miles of a state's coastline without state approval. The Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act now requires lease sales to offer at least 75% of available unleased acreage in each planning area. Additionally, the Act includes provisions for revenue sharing. The Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act is amended to allocate 40% of bonus bids and royalties from new gas leases to states and 10% for the Low-Income Home Energy Assistance Program. The Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act allocates 40% of bonus bids and royalties from new gas leases to states and 10% for the Low-Income Home Energy Assistance Program. Additionally, existing gas leases on submerged lands within state boundaries receive 10% in the first year and 20% in the second year after the enactment of the Outer Continental Shelf Natural Gas Relief Act. The Outer Continental Shelf Natural Gas Relief Act allocates increasing percentages of bonus bids and royalties from leased tracts over the years, starting at 10% in the first year and reaching 40% in the fourth year and beyond. For leased tracts partially within state boundaries, the amounts subject to this allocation vary. The Outer Continental Shelf Natural Gas Relief Act allocates increasing percentages of bonus bids and royalties from leased tracts over the years, starting at 10% in the first year and reaching 40% in the fourth year and beyond. For leased tracts partially within state boundaries, the amounts subject to this allocation vary based on the percentage of surface acreage within the seaward boundaries of the state. The Outer Continental Shelf Natural Gas Relief Act defines "existing Federal gas lease" as a lease granted before the Act's enactment and "new Federal gas lease" as a lease granted after. The Act applies to bonus bids and royalties received by the United States after September 30, 2006. Additionally, the Act amends the establishment of State Seaward Boundaries under the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act. The Act amends the establishment of State Seaward Boundaries under the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act by extending lines as indicated on specific maps for each outer Continental Shelf region. SEC. 5. NATURAL GAS-ONLY LEASING. Section 8 of the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act is amended to allow the Secretary to issue leases for the development and production of natural gas and associated condensate. Regulations must be followed regarding the definition of natural gas, condensate, and oil, as well as procedures for handling oil deposits if discovered during exploration or development. The Secretary can issue natural gas-only leases under the amended Section 8 of the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act. Regulations must be followed for handling oil deposits if discovered during exploration or development. Existing oil and gas leases can be restricted to natural gas and associated condensate only upon request. The Secretary has the authority to issue natural gas-only leases under the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act. Existing oil and gas leases can be restricted to natural gas and associated condensate upon request, following regulations. Public notice and comment are required for lease issuance.
